[103]24.  Nearly

[127]She's tied up right now. This only sets MARILYN off again. She howls with laughter and COLIN can't help joining her. 
[128]I'm sorry, Milton. I have to go. He hangs up quickly. They both laugh helplessly. MARILYN smiles. 
[129]You should get out more. See the sights. 
[130]I don't think he'd mind. 
[131]He doesn't understand your kind of actor. He's hated the method ever since Vivien worked with Elia Kazan. It's all too new and strange. You're the future, and it frightens him. 
[132]I didn't spend the night with her. We just had a chat. 
[133]She just wants a chum, that's all. 
[134]She was just being friendly. 
[135]Oh, fuck off, Dickie. You've never slept with a woman in your life. 
[136]He doesn't even know who I am. 
[137]Maybe she was trying to make him jealous... ORTON turns around frowning furiously at the voices behind the set. MILTON pushes COLIN off the set ahead of him. 
[138]I don't need your advice. And I'm not in love with her. 
[139]Oh, God... I'm sorry... I forgot... I've just been so busy. 
[140]You know how crews gossip. There's nothing in it. 
[141]Of course not. You know how crews like to gossip. His voice trails off lamely as he realises he is repeating what he has just said to Lucy. MARILYN smiles. 
[142]Lucy, I really like you. We've had such fun... 
[143]Is she okay? 
[144]Oh, Jesus - 
[145]Oh, God. If Milton sees me with you... I'll be sacked... 
[146]We have today, anyway. One day to do whatever we like. We can go back to real life tomorrow. 
[147]Well, maybe the weekend. 
[148]We could go to Windsor Castle, if you like. MARILYN's face breaks into a smile of pure delight. 
[149]My Godfather works here. He's the Royal librarian, Sir Owen Morshead. The POLICEMAN looks sceptically at Colin's casual clothes. 
[150]Clark. Colin Clark. The POLICEMAN retreats into his box. We hear him talking on the telephone. ROGER looks at COLIN. He shrugs sheepishly. 
[151]My father knows everybody. A moment later the policeman returns, looking surprised. 
[152]I'm no one. COLIN stares at MARILYN. She catches his eye and smiles, just for him. He feels like he's tumbling into the abyss, but no longer cares. 
[153]Eton is 500 years old. It was founded by King Henry VI. 
[154]Take that room up there. 
[155]That's where the boys were sent if they didn't work hard enough. Where we were whipped. 
[156]Beaten. 
[157]Five years. But I was sent to boarding school when I was eight. 
[158]That's what we do in my family. 
[159]In one way, yes. But when you're brought up in a house of over- achievers, it's hard to make your own mark. 
[160]Maybe it will be in films, but if not, there are so many possibilities out there. 
[161]But we haven't got any... He stops in mid-sentence as he sees MARILYN unbuttoning her blouse and throwing it off carelessly. 
[162]What if a boat goes past? We could be arrested. 
[163]What's wrong? 
[164]I can't see anything. 
[165]Let me warm you up.

[168]She's trying her best. 
[169]But she was wonderful yesterday. 
[170]She doesn't need pills! She just needs someone to care for her. 
[171]I told you, I'm not in love with her! 
[172]She said that? 
[173]Roger? What's the matter? 
[174]Is she dead? 
[175]How can she be asking for me if she's in a coma? 
[176]How many pills did she take?

[179]Marilyn? A shaft of moonlight reveals MARILYN lying naked across the bed, her body partly covered by the sheet. Half empty pill and champagne bottles are scattered all over her dresser; there is also an old photograph in a silver frame of her mother Gladys. 
[180]Marilyn? For a second he fears the worst, but then suddenly she groans and sits up, looking at him blearily. 
[181]Are you okay? Everyone was worried about you.

[223]I was wondering if you're doing anything this Saturday.

It is another sequence, the one where Marilyn does her sweet, uninhibited little dance (Scene 90), a performance both sexy and yet touchingly innocent. HOLD on COLIN for a long moment, gazing at her image in the darkness, then -

dialogues.SYBIL THORNDIKE:
[1]Such a lark! I long to see her. COLIN stands by the door. OLIVIER looks at his watch and shoots him a questioning glance. 
[2]How lovely you are. Here, I kept a place for you. PAULA bursts forward, steering Marilyn away instead to an empty seat on the other side of the rectangle of tables. She looks at RICHARD WATTIS, the actor occupying the seat next to the empty one. 
[3]Don't worry, dear, we won't bite. PAULA looks at her in truculent apology. 
[4]What a good idea! I wish we could all bring a friend. One does get so terribly nervous. It's just like the first day at school, isn't it? 
[5]Aren't we going to have fun? 
[6]How kind of you to meet us. Dear me, you do look cold. 
[7]How exciting! Don't you love the first day of a new production? 
[8]Oh, to be young again! She blows him a kiss and the car rolls in through the gate. Almost immediately OLIVIER's chauffeur driven Bentley appears. 
[9]Isn't she pretty though? 
[10]How kind of you, Colin. Yes, why don't we all sit down? Colin sees her chair by the camera and goes innocently to fetch it. But as he picks it up he is confronted by a stern looking crew member in overalls. 
[11]I'm sure we're all good union members here. There's no need to fall out over something so trivial.

[17]"Oh there you are my dear, I did not see you, give me a glass of that champagne I see over there. Olga Bosnia..." 
[18]"Oh yes, my dear, of course I remember you well." They all look at MARILYN... and nothing happens. 
[19]It's so easily done, isn't it? I'm sure I went wrong somewhere there too. Shall we have another go, Larry? 
[20]"Oh yes, my dear, of course I remember you well." 
[21]"What does she say?" 
[22]Didn't I have a line somewhere there, dear? 
[23]Sweetly pretty. She should use more mascara. When one is young one should use a lot of mascara, and when one is old one should use much more. What do you do, my dear?" 
[24]"Dear?" 
[25]That was perfect, Marilyn. You're Elsie to the life! MARILYN smiles awkwardly, not really believing her but SYBIL carries on with complete conviction. 
[26]Perhaps we could practise our lines together later? You'd be doing me such a kindness. At my great age it's just so hard to make them stick! Why don't you come for tea tomorrow? In fact Sybil is word perfect every time, and everyone knows it. But it is a kind and tactful gesture. MARILYN's face lights up. 
[27]Colin, dear, I thought you looked cold so I bought you this. She hands him a bright red woollen scarf. COLIN is touched.

[29]My dear, you mustn't concern yourself. A great actress like you has many other things on her mind. A radiant smile spreads slowly across Marilyn's face as the older woman's words sink in. 
[30]None of the rest of us truly know how to act for the camera. But you do. It is a rare gift. She looks sharply at OLIVIER.

[32]First love is such sweet despair, Colin. She touches his cheek gently and smiles, perhaps lost in a long ago memory of her own, before retreating quietly into the darkness at the back of the set.
dialogues.PAULA:
[1]But Marilyn is not ready. She's preparing. MARILYN glances up at COLIN in the mirror and smiles with unexpected simplicity. 
[2]I have to be next to Marilyn! The startled WATTIS gets up graciously and troops all the way around the table to the seat next to SYBIL THORNDIKE. 
[3]She likes me by her side.

[5]Locate the experience, Marilyn. Look for the memory that helps you. Remember when you went to that party at Chaplin's house and you were the only guest? How did that make you feel? This time OLIVIER stares at PAULA. 
[6]Marilyn has to begin finding the character. 
[7]The words, maybe. Not the character. RICHARD WATTIS whispers to PAUL HARDWICK. 
[8]She wasn't happy with her make- up. OLIVIER loosens his collar irritably and glances at ORTON. 
[9]You were wonderful. You are the most gifted actress I have ever known. You were superb, Marilyn. You were divine.

[11]Like this. I prayed to God on my knees. And he has given me you. You are that great actress, Marilyn.

[17]You can do it. You can't fail. You will have more pain, you will suffer more but you will create. All you need is time. 
[18]Remember, Marilyn, a tree is never just a tree. What kind of tree is Elsie? An elm tree? A birch tree?

[22]She hasn't made a sound for over an hour. 
[23]Colin, open this door! She needs me... COLIN goes back to the bed and gazes at the sleeping Marilyn, his expression suffused with a tenderness we have never seen in him before. He pulls up the sheet so that it covers her nakedness, then tentatively lies down to rest his head on the pillow. 
[24]From the first moment all I have felt is Olivier's loathing and contempt. He thinks I'm unnecessary. Me, her drama coach, surrogate mother, nursemaid. On call 24 hours a day to help her act, dole out pills, bolster her ego, keep her sober enough to work. Me. Unnecessary.  No me, no Marilyn. He is taken aback by her passion. She smiles bitterly then walks on. COLIN hesitates. She looks back briefly. 
[25]You can come up now.

[29]

dialogues.VIVIEN:

dialogues.MILLER:

Holding it to her breast and clutching the cover around her shoulders she gets up and goes into the bedroom, closing the door. As the light snaps off COLIN breathes for the first time in what feels like minutes.

dialogues.MORSHEAD:

dialogues.JANE:

[5]I have to watch Jenkins like a hawk. One more of his murderous prunings and we'll lose the tea roses for ever. And she's off again, with COLIN still following. He can't help smiling at the madness of it all.

[7]Mullins! Be an angel - find Cook and ask her how many pork chops we need for tonight. Then bring the car round. I must get to the village before the shop shuts... We can sense both his affection for it but more pressingly his need to get away. He gets in, puts the car in gear and the Bristol pulls out of the drive and across the moat. In the last rays of the sun, the countryside looks magical, but Colin only has eyes for the road ahead. 
[8]Colin, darling! How are you getting on? 
[9]How exciting. Let me see... it's Sloane 2965. Ask him if he's coming to Saltwood for the bank holiday.
